comment: Circuits II with Dr.Lee was not good. The lectures had a lot of material. The homeworks were long and difficult. The project/simulations were the only good part about the class. The tests were difficult and he didn't do a great job explaining what were on the tests.

Had him for Antenna engineering. Excellent guy. He designed Antennas for a living before teaching so his lectures are full of anecdotes and industry wisdom. Is able to answer any question you give him.

Professor lee is a great & easy grader. This course was hard & heavy project based but actually learn how to build, design, & learn how an antenna works. The course was self-paced. One thing great is he's forgiving on late submissions. Although the course was challenging, he wants you to succeed.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Electromag was insanely hard! I think Prof Lee would be good to have for in-person but the class was extra difficult being both online and in the condensed summer. The homework was hard to understand and the tests were very challenging. There were so many equations and his cheat sheets were messy/not comprehensive. Be sure to make your own!

I took Professor Lee for CIrcuits II back in Summer 2020 when everything was online, and I honestly did not expect Circuits II to be as difficult as it was, but he was pretty easy on the grading and curved our first test. Also, there will be two projects you complete during the course, but they're not very difficult, would recommend for EE 2302.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Maybe he's better in-person, but COVID has ruined that opportunity this semester. This class has been unnecessarily difficult. He grades slow, lectures are hard to follow, and his HW takes forever to finish. He decided to add a curve to the first test bc the average was a 64 despite it being open notes, but weeks later have not seen any curve added

For this Directed Study I worked on Controlled Radiation Shielding research that focuses on a modified approach of brachytherapy, a form of cancer treatment. This involved a collaboration of students to design and problem solve various challenges. Throughout the course Dr. Lee showed us how to think and operate like professional researchers!

This is one of the best engineering classes I have ever taken especially since it introduces EE students to RF engineering. First learning theory like hand calculated impedance matching and verifying with software. By the end of the semester you actually make a PCB of YOUR design that if you wanted to could send off to a manufacturer to be made!

Applied EMag is one of the fundamental fields needed for a student to eventually call themselves an Electrical Engineer and Dr. Lee does an excellent job of teaching these concepts with detailed explanation, answering questions, and help in office hours. Take Calc 3 before or during this class, it will help a lot!

Took Dr. Lee for Circuits II, also for emag and design tools. Has solidly been one of my fav professors at KSU. You need to put forth effort to understand what he teaches, esp in emag. He is very open about expectations, and is a reasonable grader. Don't assume he's a tough grader from what you hear, what he teaches is tough, so READ READ READ!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: Electromagnetics is a deep subject, to say the least. You will do LOTS of math, so brush up on Calc III. READ the emag book! Can't stress that enough. Dr. Lee is a great teacher, and cares about students who put forth effort. Make a meaningful effort to learn, and it will pay off. Super smart guy, and worth getting to know as best you can.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Lee is very interested in helping students who are INTERESTED and exhibit drive and motivation. He is a great wealth of knowledge and is worth getting to know him as best you can. He is pretty open with unscheduled hours, and more than reasonable with grading. If you're struggling, then you're doing it right. That's called learning.

Dr. Lee is one of the most intelligent professors at KSU, and one of the best professors to work with (on research) overall. The Applied EMAG course content was relatively difficult but completely worth the time, this is the only good EE elective at KSU (other than directed study).

In engineering disciplines you more or less get out what you put in. Hoseon provides material you need to learn, but your job, for the most part, is to learn it yourself. Hoseon also makes it fairly difficult to outright fail if you put in the smallest amount of "work". HW questions straight from Chegg and are 10-20% of your grade for instance. . .
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: HONEST Pros: fun guy and very open, relates topics to real-world applications, fair grader with opportunity at bonus points for projects, real experience in field with Blackberry Cons: not good at "teaching" you will learn most yourself (is hard material), very slow at grading- even if he is "busy" no excuse for 3 months late, bad at email reply
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Grades things so incredibly slow lol

Hardest EE class I took. I like him he's joking and everyting, but when it comes to explaining the information not so much. Not necessarily his fault, emag is toughest course across the board in any Uni. Hard/lots material to cover. He did okay. He is the only professor that teaches Emag currently. GL
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: As a person he's great. As a professor, he's average; nothing special. It's pretty easy to pass, fairly difficult to make an A. Hard to follow lectures sometimes; you will be teaching yourself most of the material to fully understand. Test averages have been around 50-60%
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Nothing special, no complaints though. Really smart dude, average prof.

Dr. Lee is one of the professors you hate to give a bad rating because hes a nice dude, but genuinely just isnt that great at teaching material imo. I spent a lot of time on my own learning and quite often did not return emails. He is really generous with grading; as long as you understand what to do you will be fine. Average usually is 75ish
you'll teach yourself most of the material, but easy grade

Hoseon is more interested in the research he does rather than teaching I think. Not necesarrrily a bad thing, but thats just how it is. He is a veryy easy grader (perhaps too easy I think, but still somehow the averages are 70ish on tests. He is extremely busy with a lot of work, so do not expect to be emailed back for help. Go to office hours :P

3.5!He is not that great at lecturing; I taught myself most of the material on my own. That being said, I see how it would be hard to cover everything. . . He also "lost" one of our classes test and gave everyone a 100 (very unprofessional, made some people upset bc they studied very hard). He is very easy to get along with, but somewhat scattered.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria

comment: Awesome guy. Very fair grader. Gives occasional quizzes and homework, but its not hard. Take him if you can!!!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr. Lee is very straight forward with what he wants and is easy to talk to. Best way to get a hold of him is during his office hours, and he will answer any questions you have. If you can do all the homework problems you will do fine. I enjoyed taking his class and would take again.

By far the best professor from Electrical Engineering dept. at KSU! Wish we had other professors like him: grading fair, homework assignments and tests that make sense and are consistent with what he is teaching in class. He graduated at Georgia Tech so he came with the teaching style and ideas from there. Excellent for Electromagnetics class!

Professor Lee is by far one of the best professors I've had. He is fully aware that a 50 minute lecture is nowhere near enough time to proficiently teach class like Circuits II so he went out of his way to create video lectures for the class. He does assign a vast amount of homework but he does it so that students will learn. Absolutely take him

Dr. Lee is an amazing professor and great person in general. His circuits 2 class definitely entails doing a ton of homework (which is graded), participation is graded, you'll have a few quizzes (maybe 5 or 6) and 3 tests total. By all means if you want to learn take him!!! You will not be disappointed and he grades very fairly. Take Take Take!

Dr. Lee's (good!) idea was that the bulk of the class would be dedicated to a PCB design project and report: unfortunately, the fabrication fell through, which disappointed me. There were a few tests and HW, and he was upfront and clear about their content. Class is a WIP but Lee's a good teacher and will get the kinks out in a semester or so.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: I absolutely love Dr. Lee. I had him both for Circuits 2 as well as Emag.   If you show up, participate in class,  and do the homework you will pass.  Tests are straight from the homework, he allows 1 cheat sheet per class. Don't worry too much about your grade - as long as you participate you will pass.  Defiantly would take again.

I've had him for two classes (2301 and 2302) and plan to take him for Emag. His lectures and homework are pretty brutal (Chegg is your friend), but his evaluations are usually pretty fair, and his grading is more than fair. So long as you attempt every problem, you should pass, and he barely counts off for small errors.
I had him for Circuits 2.  He is an awesome prof and really knows his material.  Super easy grader, just make sure you participate!

Lee is a genuinely good guy and mostly cares that you understand major ideas instead of getting specific numerical answers. He does seems to fumble slightly with this course sense there is so much it covers, so you will need to take time outside of class to fully understand the material. He grades fairly and adds a curve to all tests.

Lee is a cool guy and an easy professor. You will have to teach yourself a lot of the material during the semester in order to get an A, but keep in mind you only have to do better than half of the class as he curves like crazy both on tests, and on the final grade. We rushed during the last section of the semester, but otherwise the class was slow

Lee is a difficult professor, but he's teaching difficult material. He always does a review session before each test to make sure you know what concepts you're expected to work with. The test questions are usually a bit harder, though, so make sure you really know the examples or you won't do well. The problems are all long so they count for a lot.
Dr. Lee is a great teacher and if you try you will do well.

He is a Korean professor. He is a very nice person, very kind and modest. However, his lecture is pretty hard for me to understand. It seems like he only talks to himself because few people can catch up with him, and most of us always get lost after 10 minutes the class begins.
you will not Learning from him he just copy example from the book, If you wanna pass the class his okay but if you wanna learn, he will not teaching you anything.

Dr. Lee is a new professor at SPSU and is still getting a feel for his teaching style. Despite that, he did a very good job teaching Machines. He explained the concepts very well and did LOTS of examples in class. His exams were exactly like the review just with some numbers or directions changed. His future is bright at SPSU. 10/10 would recommend
Dr. Lee is a very good professor. He has a review session before every test. I really liked his teaching style and his personality and will most probably take him again.

Great professor. Dr. Lee is absolutely one of the best professors I have ever had at Southern Poly. He's very knowledgeable in his field, smart, passionate about teaching, gives good notes and is a very friendly person. I'd love to take more classes with him. Definitely recommend him to anyone who is willing to learn & cares about his future.

He just copy examples from the book without any explanations, mostly he confuse about subject  and make student c confuse, every class time he talk about his project which it is not related to the class.
